Attorney General BDWIN VAIL ABslstam TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the Consti - tution of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commissioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Commis - sioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Custer April 25, 1921 to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923 to Jan 12 1925 T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton Jan. 12, 1925 to Jan. 8 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT Lancaster Jan. 8, 1929 to Dec ] 1930 WM. H. SMITH Seward Jan. 8, 1931 to

OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER LINCOLN, NEBRASKA ..■■■■•■ . LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL November 1, 1934 Hon. Charles W. Bryan, Governor of Nebraska. My Dear Governor: Herewith I am handing you the annual report of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment and the State Tax Commissioner for the year 1934. Included in the report is a tabulation of the abstracts of assessment returned by the various county assessors, tabulations show - ing railroad assessments and apportionments, franchise valuations, and other statistical data. There have been very marked variations in valuations for taxation purposes the past four years. The year 1921 showed a total assessed valuation for the state of $3,312,737,091.00. From that year to and in - cluding 1930, there was but little change, the figure for the latter year being $3,102,050,571.00. Since 1930, to and including 1934, however, valu - ations have gone down approximately one-third, to $2,059,678,928.00. In 1921 the total state taxes levied was $10,930,607.00, and in 1930 it was $7,258,798.00, with $11,779,299.00 the high point in 1927. In 1934 the total taxes levied, based on the valuation returned by the assessors, is $4,325,326.00, the lowest in eighteen years. The greatest amount of tax levied in any one year, for all purposes, including .state, county, city, school, and miscellaneous, was in 1927, when the total reached $66,028,255.91. This had decreased to $42,906, - 527.94 in 1933. The figures for 1934 were not available at the time this portion of the report was prepared, but will be found in a table in the latter part of the publication. Land Values A comparison of the assessed valuation of lands over a period of years, showing the rise and fall, is interesting, and the following table has been compiled. It shows the average assessed value per acre in 1908, in 1913, in 1929, when values reached the highest point, and in 1934. It will be observed lands are now taxed in nearly all counties for less than they were taxed twenty-one years ago, and in many counties for less than they were taxed twenty-six years ago The figures by counties are as follows:

REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER The total acreage for the state and the average assessed valuation per acre, for the various years was as follows: Yeap Acreage Average 1908 34,086,930 $29.80 1913 40,203,007 31.30 1929 46,187,544 38.60 1934 46,669,712 24.43 Due to the variation in the total acreage caused by new lands being added to the tax rolls, particularly in the sand-hill regions where values are the lowest, the comparison of the average value for the whole state one year with the other is not a fair one, but a fair comparison may b« made of the valuation in various counUes for the various years. All Other Property, excluding intangible 27.849,272 .013,522 20 - Total $2,059,678,928 1.000,000 No Litigation The State Board of Equalization and Assessment has been fortunate the past three years in having become involved in no litigation with the railroads, or other tax paying agencies. The valuation of railroad prop-

STATE OF NEBRASKA erty for taxation, purposes is determined by the board and apportioned to the counties, in accordance with the mileage therein. Following a suggestion contained in a court decision a number of years ago, the board, since then, has used as a basis for taxation the market value of the stocks and bonds of such companies. In 1931 the board adopted the plan of utilizing a four-year average in determining the valuation. The purpose of this was to avoid the sudden and decided fluctuation in valu - ations as indicated by the slump in the value of stocks and bonds, and to retain a more nearly even valuation from year to year. Prior to 1934 the trend had been decidedly downward, and had the 1933 valuation alone been used for assessment purposes, the value of railroad property as determined by the stocks and bonds method would have been prac - tically nil. By 1934 there was a marked Increase in valuations. As a re - sult of the four-year average, the valuation for that year was less than would have been obtained from the single year method, but on the other hand the 1931, 1932 and 1933 values were materially higher. The reduc - tion in the valuation of railroad property over the period of years has been very much in line with the reduction in the value of other classes <>f property. The method employed has seemed fair to all, and no ap - peals have been taken from the board's action since 1931. This appeal was taken by the Chicago & Northwestern Ry. Co., and is still pending in the federal court. Board Should Tax Other Property I am convinced companies operating telephone lines, pipe lines and power lines, at least those doing an inter-county business, should be taxed by the state board also, rather than within the county, and the valuation apportioned to the counties through a method similar to that employed in apportioning railroad valuations. This would provide a more uniform assessed valuation in the various counties, and 1 believe prove more satisfactory than the present system, which was adopted when the state was new, and before the development of any of these public utilities. Franchise Valuations The state board is confronted annually with the problem of finding franchise valuations for certain corporations. Representatives of most of the companies appearing before the board argue the law is unfair, and unconstitutional. It has not been attacked in the courts, however, and as long as it stands on the statute, it is the duty of the board to enforce it. My own view is that the franchise tax law is more of an equalizing measure than anything else, and that if the public utilities in question were taxed by the state board, a value could be determined for them that would virtually eliminate the need or a franchise valuation. After taxing the railroads the board certainly could not be expected to, and

REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER the law does not contemplate it shall, add to the valuation it has deter - mined an additional valuation under the guise of a franchise. Intangible Tax Act The 1933 session of the Legislature revised and amended what is known as the intangible tax act, but the new measure was held uncon - stitutional by the supreme court. As a result, the taxing authorities are back where they were before the 1933 act was passed, and some additional change in the old law may be made by the 1935 legislative session. The Court's decision was not handed down until after the work of assessing was well under way. The old law provided for separ - ate schedules for tangible and intangible returns. The new law merged the two schedules, and no matter what else may be done to the act, it is the hope of those administering the tax laws that one rather than two schedules may be provided for the future. State Finances There has been considerable agitation in recent years for new methods of raising public revenue, but as yet no change has been made in the general plan for taxation. The state's finances are now in splendid shape, in spite of the adverse conditions that have prevailed for several years past, and this is due in a large measure to the economic methods employed by your administration. If the state had a depleted treasury, advocates of new methods of taxation could make much more progress than they have been able to make with the state's finances in a sound condition. In Conclusion I want to thank you, as well as the other members of the board, foi - the cooperation extended in handling tax problems. I want to express my appreciation to you also for the splendid corps of assistants supplied the department the past four years. These are: Minnie B. Smith, Chief Clerk Edna R. Wellman, Distribution Clerk Florence Thomas, Stenographer Alice McCormick, Bookkeeper Minnie Adsit, Bookkeeper-Clerk Irene Walters, Clerk In addition to the tax work there has been merged in this office the finance department, which is the accounting agency for all departments under the direct control of the Governor, and the bureau of the budget. Tb!e purchasing agent directs a bureau also affiliated with this depart - ment. The force assigned the office has handled the work of all these

STATE QF NEBRASKA activities, except that of the purchasing agent, with hut very little extra help. The cost of operation has materially decreased, the appropria - tion for the 1929-30 biennium having totaled $60,000.00 as compared to $45,000.00 for the present biennium. A vast amount of relief work, incident to the President's recovery program, has been handled in the department during the organization period, and the expense met from our own funds. The county assessors of the state have rendered fine service during the past four years, and I am grateful to them for their cooperation also. Respectfully submitted. State Tax Commissioner

REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 4. Rolling Stock Assessment The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Sec - tion 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, giving the total valuation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city or village. This amount is then certified to the county clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which Is made by the local assessor and equalized by the State Board. REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT No. 6 State Levy for 1934. RESOLUTION WHEREAS, from the auditor's report, it appears that there was appropriated to be paid out of the general fund, the sum of $11 012 667 41 for the biennium of 1933-4, one-half of which, plus the emergency and claims appropriations of $304,146.98, were met from the revenues of 1933 with the remainder to be met from the revenues of 1934 in the sum of $ 5,506,332.00 And, Whereas, there will be available from miscellaneous collections for the general fund not otherwise appropriated, receipts estimated at..$l,059,273.45 Plus general fund collections from the in - tangible tax, estimated at $ 106,986.54 Plus beer tax on hand $ 142*399*52 $1,308,659.51 Balance 54 giv 49 which amount is increased 3 per cent in accordance with House Roll 189, Session Laws of 1927 $ 125,930.17 Leaving to be raised from the general fund levy $4,323,602.66 The assessed valuation of the tangible property of the state for 1934, as of record in the office of the Tax Com - missioner is $2,059,678,928, applied to which sum a levy of 2.1 mills will raise $4,325,325.75 THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the General Fund levy for 1934 be 2.1 mills, which will produce the estimated sum of $4,325,325.75 The following General Fund Receipts from July 1, 1933 to June 30 1934 go to^make up the miscellaneous collections referred to in the foregoing resolution.
